Title: As an admin, when adding transitions or deleting steps on an active workflow, I want improved guidance to the error message You cannot perform this operation on a draft workflow
Description: As frustrations with this error [continue to persist|https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Jira-questions/You-cannot-perform-this-operation-on-a-draft-workflow/qaq-p/133114#M234561], it might be helpful to better-steer users to helpful solutions in the following ways:   * Change the [More Information|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver073/working-with-workflows-861253510.html#ConfiguringWorkflow-Limitationswheneditinganactiveworkflow] link on this error to [the other link that should have been used|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jirakb/cannot-add-transitions-or-delete-steps-in-draft-workflows-203392961.html]   * Remove the sentence *When you edit an active workflow, JIRA first creates a draft of it, that you can then modify +_as you see fit_+* from the [More Information|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver073/working-with-workflows-861253510.html#ConfiguringWorkflow-Limitationswheneditinganactiveworkflow] page, as as you see fit is not true and multiple-year old problems persist e.g. JRACLOUD-17782.   * Outline the (8-step) workaround required to add status/transitions to a default workflow (since modifying the default workflow is not possible due to it being active upon project setup):   ** navigate to workflows   ** duplicate the current workflow   ** change the name of the duplicated workflow (but you can't use the active workflow name and can't change the active workflow name, so you are forced to use something entirely different)   ** add the status/transition   ** navigate to the workflow scheme   ** change the workflow in the scheme   ** navigate back to workflows   ** delete the default workflow

Name: Atlassian Jira Cloud
Title: The Editing a project key documentation page for JIRA Cloud misses the Notes for change management and Notes for developers sections that are available in the same page for JIRA Server
Description: h3. Summary     Almost all the information present in the below documentation page for JIRA Server is missing for JIRA Cloud:  - JIRA Server page: https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver075/editing-a-project-key-935391076.html  - JIRA Cloud page: https://confluence.atlassian.com/jiracorecloud/editing-a-project-s-details-938021482.html    \\  Specifically the sections named *Notes for change management* and *Notes for developers* contain very useful information that should be available to Cloud users as well:    {quote}  *Notes for change management*    While editing the project key is a major change, in most cases, your JIRA project will work as you'd expect with a new key. There are a few cases that you should be <USER>of, which are listed below. We recommend reviewing these and advising your users accordingly.  - The old project key can be used in JQL queries — Users won't have to update issue filters that reference the old project key.  If you use Confluence with JIRA, the JIRA issue macros in Confluence will continue to work. Please note, if you don't see the change straight away, allow some time for the cache to refresh.  - You won't be able to create a new project with the old project key. However, you can change the renamed project back to the old project key. If you delete the project, all associated keys will be freed and you'll be able to re-use them.  - Links will work, whether they are inside JIRA or from external sources. However, link aliases will not be updated — For example, if you have a link to an issue 'EXAMPLE-1' in the description of an issue, and you change the project key 'EXAMPLE' to 'DEMO', then the alias 'EXAMPLE-1' will not be updated to 'DEMO-1'. The link will still direct you to DEMO-1 though.  - If you are using a gadget with a global filter, you will need to update the filter after the project is renamed.  - All attachments will be accessible after the project key change. Please note however, that the directory that they are stored in (under the <JIRA Home>\data\attachments directory) will be retain the old project key. For example, if you change a project's key from TEST to DEMO, the attachments will be stored under <JIRA Home>\data\attachments\TEST.  - If you export a renamed project, then import it, it will have the updated project key, i.e. the original project key will not be retained. In fact, all historical keys for that project will be removed. There is a workaround for this that involves changing data directly in your database, see [this Answers post|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/257060/renaming-and-importing-a-project-where-has-the-old-project-key-history-gone-redirects-search?page=1#257061].  {quote}    {quote}  *Notes for developers*    - REST API calls will still work with old project key — REST calls that specify an issue key will work with the old issue key after the project key has changed. For example, /rest/api/issue/EXAMPLE-100 will still work after the project key is changed from EXAMPLE to DEMO.  - We have created a new event, ProjectUpdatedEvent. This event is triggered any time a project's details are changed, including changing the project key.  - If you need to retrieve all issue keys and project keys (historical and current), you can do this via the following:  -* REST:  Get all project keys for a project: /rest/api/2/project/<project key>?expand=projectKeys  -* Java API:  -*- Get all project keys: com.atlassian.<USER>project.ProjectManager#getAllProjectKeys  -*- Get all issue keys for an issue: com.atlassian.<USER>issue.IssueManager#getAllIssueKeys  {quote}

Name: Atlassian Jira Cloud
Title: Unable to remove customware application links
Description: Last deployment on OnDemand has upgraded the applinks to 4.0  The Customware Core Connector plugin seems to be using an older version of Applinks. It looks like this version mismatch is now causing issues when trying to remove Application links using this plugin. When trying to remove a link the following message shows:          h2. Workaround    Using Chrome or Firefox click on the *X* icon to delete the Application Link, right click on the *Confirm* button, click on *Inspect Element* and locate  the following string:    {quote}  <button class=button-panel-button wizard-submit disabled=disabled>.   {quote}    Remove the *disabled=disabled* (right click on it and hit delete) and click on *Confirm* again, the Application Link should be deleted properly.

Name: Atlassian Jira Cloud
Title: Displaying the worklog panel or a report with a very large number of worklog entries is a complete fail
Description: h5.to reproduce  - Add 3000 worklog entries and then goto the worklog panel, wait a long time. Add a new work log while on this panel,  wait a *very, very, very long while* (If you are just on the comment panel, you can add a worklog in sensible time.)  - In Tempo TImesheets plugin, try to fetch a report for multiple issues and a time period long enough to include thousands of worklog entries    This may cause JIRA to run out of memory altogether.     *Possible workaround:*  If you are using the tempo plugin, fetch reports for shorter periods of time. If the default settings are set to a long time span, visit this URL: YOUR_SERVER/secure/TempoUserBoard!timesheet.jspa?periodView=WEEK to get a weekly report.

Name: Atlassian Jira Cloud
Title: Issue creation throws clauseValue should not be null error when notification cannot be sent to HipChat
Description: h5.summary  When a postfunction is added to issue creation transition in the workflow, the issue might have not yet been persisted in database when the postfunction is executed, causing exceptions when running JQL filter.    h5.steps to reproduce  # add a 'Notify HipChat' transition Post Function to the Create Issue transition in a workflow;  # Specify a JQL filter for this postfunction  # attempt to create an issue using the workflow from step 1.    *Expected result:* issue is created (ideally with a warning that notification cannot be sent to a missing room).    *Actual result:* an UI error  {quote}Error creating issue: root cause: clauseValue should not be null!{quote}    and a stack trace in the logs:        h5.workaround  Delete the Post Function referring to HipChat, or its JQL filter. Alternatively, try changing the order of post function to be after issue creation.

Notes + Workaround The issue seems to happen when a project is imported from Trello, then removed and imported again. Name: Atlassian Jira Cloud
Title: JIRA Cloud Import Documentation Update required Missing critical info
Description: {panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}   *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://<USER>atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-64004].   {panel}  h3. Problem Definition  The JIRA Cloud Document: [Import and export data |https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/import-and-export-data-744721621.html]  for step 1 refers to JIRA applications [Importing issues |https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiracloud/importing-issues-776636788.html] This document details at Point 2 step 1: {quote}2. Import the data  1. Upload the files to the cloud by [using WebDAV |https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/upload-data-via-webdav-744721622.html]. (For backup files larger than 4GB, refer to [Uploading Large files to WebDAV |https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloudkb/uploading-large-files-to-webdav-747834468.html]) {quote} The first link: [using WebDAV |https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/upload-data-via-webdav-744721622.html] is a reciprocal link back to document 1 with no additional information  The Second Link [Uploading Large files to WebDAV |https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloudkb/uploading-large-files-to-webdav-747834468.html] Notes the Deprication of the webdav with: {quote}(!) Atlassian Cloud applications no longer support WebDAV. For updated import information, please refer to [Import and export data |https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/import-and-export-data-744721621.html]. {quote} The link provided [Import and export data |https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/import-and-export-data-744721621.html] is also a link back to the first document with no additional information on the new process for uploading data for a Import. h3. Suggested Solution  The new process needs to be detailed in the import documentation directly.  Since of the Depreciation of the WebDav the new process has been added in the Cloud instance directly on the *Second Step* of the *JIRA Import Wizard* So the only way to notified of the new process is to initiate the process before reading the documentation pages as you must start the import to reveal these details: {quote} h2.Before you begin # Back up your JIRA Cloud site data using Backup Manager  # Prepare an export of your other JIRA Cloud or Server instance.  # If you want to include attachments, avatars, or logos in this import, create compressed copies of the following:  * <JIRA_HOME>/data/attachments directory (with attachments as the top-level directory, or project keys within attachments as the top-level directory).  * <JIRA_HOME>/data/avatars directory (with avatars as the top-level directory)  * <JIRA_HOME>/logos directory (with logos as the top-level directory) {quote} !Screen Shot 2017-02-06 at 4.41.01 PM.png|thumbnail!  Between step 2 and 3 the JIRA Import File only file is uploaded from local file system to the webdav, and there is still no indication of were in the process attachments, avatars, or logos files are to be uploaded. Step 3 Notes: {quote} Before the import is started, the JIRA export and optional archives must be uploaded to your Atlassian Cloud instance using WebDAV. For instructions on connecting to your WebDAV directory, [see this documentation | http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/Cloud/Uploading+Data+via+WebDAV]. The import data must be at the root-level of your WebDAV directory and not within a sub-folder. {quote} *Also Redirecting to the first document:* [Import and export data | https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/import-and-export-data-744721621.html] with no indication of how or when to do this. !Screen Shot 2017-02-06 at 4.48.33 PM.png|thumbnail!  Next step Initiates the Restore  Once Restore is successful to upload the Attachments/Avatars/logos  you have to Do the process again but this time upload the <USER>of the attachments rather than the <USER>backup,  once complete repeat for each subsequent ZIP file so in total you will need to repeat the full migration process four time to transfer all data once for each: - <USER>backup.<USER>- attachments.<USER>- avatars.<USER>- logos.<USER>

Title: Documentation Update for JQL Search with Special Characters
Description: {panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}   *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://<USER>atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-63730].   {panel}  h2. Definition  As per this [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jiracoreserver072/search-syntax-for-text-fields-829092675.html], it should be possible to search in the issue navigator using special characters. {quote}  JIRA supports the ability to search issues for special characters by escaping them in your query syntax. The current list of such characters is:  {quote}  However, it is not working as expected. Searching like summary !~ *\\] fails with error The text query '*\]' for field 'summary' is not valid: the '*' and '?' are not allowed as first character in wildcard query and summary !~ \\] returns all the issues.   I came across to this [bug report|https://<USER>atlassian.com/browse/JRA-40790] which was eventually not closed as *Answered*.  {quote} To do this we use Lucene's ClassicTokenizer which: # Splits words at punctuation characters, removing punctuation. However, a dot that's not followed by whitespace is considered part of a token. # Splits words at hyphens, unless there's a number in the token, in which case the whole token is interpreted as a product number and is not split. # Recognizes email addresses and internet hostnames as one token.  As a result the [ and ] characters are neither added to the index or retained in the phrase query. {quote}  There were comments about documentation update to avoid confusion but there was no follow up whether a ticket has been created for that or not. So here it is.

[See the corresponding suggestion|http://<USER>atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-63693].   {panel}  As a <USER> I'd like to know how JIRA is dealing with the attachment structure when creating the subfolders inside the attachment directory.  For example:  Let's say that your TEST project has the last issue key *TEST-4321*. Name: Atlassian Jira Cloud
Title: Difference between Day & Time search is not explained in any JQL documentation
Description: {panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}   *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://<USER>atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-62871].   {panel}  Problem Definition  For example, searching for {{-1d}} vs {{-24h}} in query gives completely different results. However this is not highlighted or explained in our documentation.  * When specifying {{-1d}}, it will start calculating on the day when you executed it (which includes today itself if you execute the query now). It does not take into account the amount of time relative to the time you had executed it, ie 24 hours from the time you executed the JQL.  * When specifying {{-24h}}, it will start calculating from the hour when you executed it, ie 24 hours from the time you executed the JQL.  Let's assume there is an issue that was transitioned to Closed yesterday 3PM, and the query is executed 1PM today:  * {{status changed to Closed after -1d}} will not return the result but {{status changed to Closed after -2d}} will  * {{status changed to Closed after -24h}} will return the result  Suggested Solution  Include a section in Advanced JQL Search documentation to explain the differences.

Title: explain differences btwn CSV importer and JIM plugin
Description: {panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}   *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://<USER>atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-60871].   {panel}  The documentation for [creating issues using the CSV importer|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRACORESERVER071/Creating+issues+using+the+CSV+importer] seems to have been copied from the [Importing data from CSV|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/AdminJIRAServer071/Importing+data+from+CSV] document (using the JIRA Importers plugin).  However, there are several differences in functionality and behavior for using the CSV Importer vs the JIRA Importers Plugin (JIM). One example would be importing issues with Components or Labels - The JIRA Importer Plugin would create the missing entries for those fields, however, the CSV Importer will fail because the components / labels do not exist.  It would be great to have those differences documented (e.g. mentioned in the *Tips for importing CSV data into issue fields* section for each field).  Having a table / matrix with all the fields which can be imported and also how they differ on each imported would be the ideal.

Description: {panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}   *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://<USER>atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-60645].   {panel}  h3. Problem Definition  Migration from JIRA Server to Cloud has currently this bug: https://<USER>atlassian.com/browse/JRA-60588  Basically, if the user migrate from JIRA Server to Cloud and the System timezone is different, this will cause a serious problem where dates are actually changed on migration. Description: {panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}   *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://<USER>atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-60539].   {panel}  The [email handler documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiracloud/creating-issues-and-comments-from-email-779288896.html#Creatingissuesandcommentsfromemail-messagehandlersMailhandlers] for [Create a new issue from each email message|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiracloud/creating-issues-and-comments-from-email-779288896.html#Creatingissuesandcommentsfromemail-Createanewissuefromeachemailmessage] is wrong. Indeed, for the *Project* field, it says: {quote} *Project*  Specify the project key of the default project to which new issues are created by this handler — for example, JRA. +Note:+ This field is only relevant for issue creation, not for issue commenting. If an email message contains an issue key in its subject line and that issue key exists in your JIRA installation, the handler will add the email message content as a comment on the issue, regardless of which project the issue is in.  {quote}  The above text is the same as the one for [Create a new issue or add a comment to an existing issue|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiracloud/creating-issues-and-comments-from-email-779288896.html#Creatingissuesandcommentsfromemail-Createanewissueoraddacommenttoanexistingissue], but then if that was the case there wouldn't be any difference among the 2.  Indeed, if I reply to a notification from ISSUE-A, I have the email handler configured to [Create a new issue from each email message|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiracloud/creating-issues-and-comments-from-email-779288896.html#Creatingissuesandcommentsfromemail-Createanewissuefromeachemailmessage] and the *Project* field is set to PROJECT-Y. Then my reply will create a new issue in PROJECT-Y instead of adding a comment to ISSUE-A.

Title: Improve Documentation on Custom Field Contexts
Description: {panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}   *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://<USER>atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-60488].   {panel}  The only reference for Custom Field contexts in our official documentation is: {quote} h3. Adding a new context  Adding a new context allows you to configure a custom field differently for different combinations of issue types and projects.  *To add a new context:* # Navigate to the Custom Fields page, locate the desired custom field and choose cog icon > Configure. # Click the Add new context link. The 'Add configuration scheme context' page will be displayed (see below). #* Under 'Add configuration scheme context', enter a 'Label' and 'Description' for your new context — these are used for administrative purposes only and will not be shown to your end-users. #* Under 'Choose applicable issue types', select the issue type(s) to which you want this Default Value and Options to apply. You can select Any issue types if you wish. #* Under 'Choose applicable contexts', select the project(s) to which you want this Default Value and Options to apply. Note that this will apply to only issues with the selected issue type(s) as above.  A custom field can only have one context per JIRA project. So you cannot have multiple contexts for different issue types in the same project. {quote} Source: [Configuring a Custom Field|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Configuring+a+Custom+Field]  This leaves room for a lot of questions on how contexts work and what happens after a new context is created for an existing field (e.g. when there are existing issues with populated values).  We need to clarify that even if the options from the Default Configuration are the same as the ones used in a context, once a context is created, the old values will be rendered obsolete / read only.  Related bugs and docs: * [JRA-33026|https://<USER>atlassian.com/browse/JRA-33026] - Additional configuration context caused missing value for field with optionid * [Change Context for an Existing Custom Field Without Losing Old Data|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/Change+Context+for+an+Existing+Custom+Field+Without+Losing+Old+Data]

Name: Atlassian Jira Cloud
Title: Update Rest API documentation to clarify about /rest/api/2/user/properties/{propertyKey}
Description: {panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://<USER>atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-60326].  {panel}  h3. Problem Definition    Currently JIRA has a new REST API call for user properties. However, the documentation is not clear on the specifics of this call as explained by the dev in the below 2 comments to linked issues:   # JRACLOUD-45502:  {quote}The user properties that can be set via the user profile page and the user properties exposed in the JIRA REST API are actually two completely different storage mechanisms, which explains why user properties set from EditUserProperties.jspa are not returned when you call the REST API.    The new user properties in the REST API are intended to be used by remote integrations and add-ons to store per-user data and settings. This helps add-ons provide a customized experience for each JIRA user while keeping all the data in the JIRA Cloud instance's database. These properties are generally intended to be used by add-ons. We do not plan to build a UI to create and set properties – you are more than welcome to use them, but to retrieve user properties using a GET request on /rest/api/2/user/properties, they must be set with a PUT to /rest/api/2/user/properties/\{propertyKey}.    We absolutely recognize the confusion that having two different sets of user properties can cause, and we intend to rectify this in the future.  {quote}   # JRACLOUD-59760:  {quote}There is a [free add-on for JIRA Cloud|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.connect.entity-property-tool.prod/cloud/overview] that provides the ability to edit user entity properties, which are [accessible via the user entity properties REST API discussed on this issue|https://docs.atlassian.com/<USER>REST/cloud/#api/2/user/properties].     We know that one of the most common use cases for user properties is workflow automation. For that reason, add-ons like the new [JIRA Misc Workflow Extensions add-on for JIRA Cloud|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.innovalog.jmwe.<USER>misc-workflow-extensions/cloud/overview] have also implemented their own user interfaces for setting and managing user properties.    The reason we are not planning to expose a REST API for the legacy user preferences/properties that are currently not accessible via REST is that we are making a number of changes to how users are stored in Atlassian Cloud as we roll out [Atlassian accounts|https://confluence.atlassian.com/purchasing/introducing-atlassian-account-738362254.html]. Unfortunately, migrating legacy user preferences to the new user entity properties available via REST is not straightforward.  {quote}        Therefore, users would be attempting to access properties of users created via UI using REST API and also will expect to access properties created via REST API from the UI. However, this is an intended behavior as explained in the above tickets.  h3. Suggested Solution    Please update the doc to clarify the rest call as explained by the dev

Name: Atlassian Jira Cloud
Title: Documentation request: Indicate possible performance problems with Java 7 and JIRA 6.3.x+
Description: {panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}   *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://<USER>atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-60023].   {panel}  h4. Problem The supported platforms documentation for [JIRA 6.3.x|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jira063/supported-platforms-683541780.html] and [6.4.x|https://confluence.atlassian.com/<USER>supported-platforms-207488170.html] currently states that Java 7 and 8 are both supported. Although the application functions properly with Java 7, but there are a large number of cases - especially when it comes to medium to large instances - when the performance on Java 7 is significantly worse than it is on Java 8, not to talk about the same instance running on earlier versions of JIRA.  h4. Proposed solution We already have a [knowledge base article|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/Java+8+improves+JIRA+application+performance+dramatically] that describes the performance gain on Java 8, but customers who upgrade or install JIRA will not necessarily browse through the KB space.   We should mention the significant performance impact when using Java 7 in both the supported platforms documentation and the related upgrade documentation to clarify the situation and avoid post-mortem suggestions for customers being affected by this issue.  We should probably also evaluate removing Java 7 as supported platform for these versions, given the number of performance related issues we see.  h5. References - [*Java 8 improves JIRA application performance dramatically*|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/Java+8+improves+JIRA+application+performance+dramatically] - [JIRA 6.3.x supported platforms|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jira063/supported-platforms-683541780.html] - [JIRA 6.4.x supported platforms|https://confluence.atlassian.com/<USER>supported-platforms-207488170.html] - [JIRA 6.3 upgrade notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/<USER><USER>6-3-upgrade-notes-596771073.html] - [JIRA 6.4 upgrade notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/<USER><USER>6-4-upgrade-notes-687014821.html] - [Upgrading JIRA|https://confluence.atlassian.com/<USER>upgrading-<USER>185729508.html]

Name: Atlassian Jira Cloud
Title: Document how Add-on license is checked when there are multiple Applications with different User-tiers
Description: {panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}   *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://<USER>atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-59991].   {panel}  h4. +Summary+ In JIRA 7, it's possible that each Application uses a different User-tier for its license. It seems that an add-on license is always checked against the Application with the higher/highest User-tier.  h4. +Scenario+ # Install JIRA Software 7 # Use JIRA Software 10-user license # Use JIRA Core 25-user license # Install an add-on and use a 10-user license for it  The add-on can be configured to be used by only those users who have JIRA Software access, however this doesn't matter as the add-on license is checked against JIRA Core license, which makes it *incompatible*.  (i) The same behavior is observed when JIRA Software uses 25-user license and JIRA Core uses 10-user license.  h4. +Suggestion+ Since this seems to be the way UPM has always checked for add-on licenses, it should be well documented somewhere. This is necessary in JIRA 7, where each application can use a different user-tier.  (!) Another suggestion may be to make it possible for an add-on to only work with one specific application, against which its license is checked.

Title: Clarify documentation for using Project Import tool
Description: {panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}   *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://<USER>atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-59713].   {panel}  The documentation for JIRA Software 7.0's Project Import tool, at [https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver070/restoring-a-project-from-backup-749383456.html], lacks clarity when it comes to importing Agile-style JIRA projects.  Please revise the documentaiton to address the following four issues, numbered A, B, C & D:  A) When importing JIRA Agile projects from one JIRA Software 7.0 system to another, the user is in a Catch-22 situation regarding workflows.  The Project Import documentation states:  {color:#14892c}If you wish to retain a customized workflow from your backup, you will need to create a new workflow in your target JIRA instance and manually edit the new workflow (e.g. create steps and transitions) to reflect your old workflow  . . . Do not use the JIRA functionality for exporting and importing workflow XML definitions, to copy your backup workflow to your target JIRA instance. {color}  However, when it comes to Aglie projects, the workflow itself contains comments which contradict the above documentation:  {color:#654982}This workflow is managed internally by JIRA Agile. Do not manually modify this workflow{color}  Please provide clarification what to do specifically regarding workflows when importing Agile-style projects:  1) Should the workflow be recreated manually? 2) Should the workflow be exported as XML, then imported on the target system and manually revised? 3) Or is it best to use the workflow that is created when the empty project is first created on the target system?  B) When creating the new empty projects on the target system, is it OK to create a non-Agile project, then later associate the project with an Agile workflow?  Or must the new empty projects be created as Agile projects from the start (via an Agile-enabled project template)?  C) I often assign the same workflow to multiple non-Aglie projects.  Is it possible for Agile projects to have shared workflows?  Or must each Agile project have a distinct workflow?  D) Please provide some sample SQL queries that could be used to re-establish Boards and other Agile data that the JIRA Software 7.0 Import Tool currently skips.  So far, the best procedure I have found is at [https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/18448856/how-to-import-<USER>agile-sprint-data-project-by-project], but there is no way for me to know whether these steps are correct and complete.

Name: Atlassian Jira Cloud
Title: Clarify the meaning of snapshot in the -backing up data- documentation
Description: {panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}   *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://<USER>atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-59424].   {panel}  As per costumer feedback: {quote} It may be better to exclude the whole /<USER>home/caches/ directory all together, as it looks like this is just temporary content as well as the indexes. There is also the tmp folder, which looks to be the same kind of thing. I'd guess those two locations are the most likely to be modified during a copy.  I've tried copying the HOME folder without either of those two directories (using exclude commands in rsync) and Jira actually starts up fine without them. It re-creates them when it first runs and starts to fill them with content again. The index page says that the index is missing and that it should be restored and re-built; re-creating it only took 6 minutes or our test system.  I think it would be very good to update the documentation in light of all this. Right now, it says create a snapshot of the data directory (including all files and subdirectories), then back up the snapshot:  https://confluence.atlassian.com/<USER>backing-up-data-185729581.html  I think it would be better and clearer to say:  The recommended method of backing up the data directory is to copy it to another location while excluding both the /<USER>data/caches/ and /<USER>data/tmp folders, and then to archive the copied folder (using <USER> tar.gz, etc). This is because the content in those two folders is frequently modified, which may cause the copy to fail, and because Jira will simply re-create these folders and their content if they are missing.  NOTE: the Jira index is stored inside the caches directory, so will be lost using this method. You can enable restorable index in the system options to create backups of the index, which you can then restore later. Alternatively, if time is available, you can re-create the index from scratch after you have restored Jira.  Here is an example rsync command for the copy:  rsync -avh --delete --exclude 'caches' --exclude 'tmp' --stats --progress /<USER>data/ /<USER>rsync/    That would definately have helped me when I was configuring the backup. {quote}

[See the corresponding suggestion|http://<USER>atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-44654].   {panel}  Cookie based authentication is recommended on Cloud instances because the basic authentication of rest api requests uses many resources. Using basic authentication can lead to performance problems and even full Cloud application locks when it scales.  [JIRA REST API Tutorials|https://developer.atlassian.com/display/JIRADEV/JIRA+REST+API+Tutorials] mention the use of cookie based authentication but there are no examples or guides on it. Name: Atlassian Jira Cloud
Title: Ambiguous swapGroup parameter in Delete Group REST API
Description: {panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}   *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://<USER>atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-44332].   {panel}  According to REST API documentation for Delete Group, you can pass a swapGroup query param (which is optional) which is a group to transfer visibility restrictions of the group that is being deleted.   One could expect that passing the param would result in replacing deleted group with swapped group in all schemes (permission, notification, issue security) but also comments and worklogs where you restricted visibility. Which is not true. The group is swapped only for comments and worklogs. Someone decided that visibility restrictions stands only for these two entities. However you do restrict visibility of an issue by setting its security level, don't you?  Probably we can't change behaviour of the resource (it's part of API) and underlying GroupService, but we can at least document it better, as is the GroupService#deleteGroup documented, so it's clear what will get swapped.  We'd also consider retiring GroupService#deleteGroup and DELETE /group?swapGroup behaviour in favour of swapping groups in comments and worklogs but also all schemes, which will make it consistent with RoleService and DELETE /role implementation, which (will) swap role in comments, worklogs, and schemes.

You will need the backup file of data from your old JIRA that you created earlier in these instructions (above).  To import your old JIRA data into your new JIRA:  Log in as a user with the '<USER>USER> global permission.{quote} After JIRA has been restarted, the user will be directed to the startup wizard - which asks users to set up a new <USER>instance, or back up from XML. Name: Atlassian Jira Cloud
Title: The Rapid Upgrade documentation should clearly explain how to migrate customisations
Description: {panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}   *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://<USER>atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-41314].   {panel}  In the Rapid Upgrade Method documentation (https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Upgrading+JIRA+Using+a+Rapid+Upgrade+Method), the following steps are provided to guide customers on how to migrate their customisations: {quote} iv. Start your new (upgraded) JIRA installation. (!) If you noted any files that contain customizations which must be migrated manually to your upgraded JIRA installation (above), then: 1. Stop the upgraded JIRA installation. 2. Migrate the customizations from these files into the upgraded JIRA Installation Directory. 3. Restart the upgraded JIRA installation. {quote}  This is not clear enough, since the customisations must be manually entered in the new files once the installation is completed. Copying the files from the old installation might cause many problems, as there might be changes in the default files from the old to the new version which won't be carried over.  This procedure is actually better explained in our other document for the [manual upgrade method|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Upgrading+JIRA+Manually#UpgradingJIRAManually-4.Postupgradechecksandtasks]: {quote} 3.4 Migrate your existing JIRA configurations over to your new JIRA installation If you have modified properties in configuration files of your existing JIRA installation, make the same modifications in your new JIRA installation. However, because the properties in the configuration files may have changed between versions, you cannot simply copy the configuration files from your existing installation and replace the equivalent files in the new installation.  For each file you have modified in your existing JIRA installation, you need to *manually edit each equivalent file in your new JIRA installation and re-apply your modifications.* If a file is not present in your new JIRA installation (for example, osuser.xml in recent JIRA versions), then simply copy that file over to your new JIRA installation. {quote}

Name: Atlassian Jira Cloud
Title: Update Mail Handler Documentation
Description: {panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}   *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://<USER>atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-38662].   {panel}  After did some further investigation in https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JSP-193355 support request, it seem  our [Create a new issue or add a comment to an existing issue|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Creating+Issues+and+Comments+from+Email#CreatingIssuesandCommentsfromEmail-Createanewissueoraddacommenttoanexistingissue] article information is not complete.  Perhaps, we can include the following details:  {quote} An email is classified as 'bulk' if any of the following is true: * The first 'Precedence' header in the message is 'bulk' * The message is a multipart/report message and the content type contains 'report-type=delivery-status' * The message is not a multipart/report message and the Return-Path is <> * The message contains the header Auto-Submitted with a value different than no  If an email is 'bulk', there are three possible actions: * The mail is ignored, the debug log should have the line Ignoring email with bulk delivery type, adds the log line 'Rejecting message due to failed bulk check.' and the issue/comment *is not* created. * The mail is forwarded, the debug log should have the line Forwarding email with bulk delivery type, adds the log line 'Rejecting message due to failed bulk check.' and the issue/comment *is not* created. * The mail is deleted, the debug log should have the line Deleting email with bulk delivery type, adds the log line 'Rejecting message due to failed bulk check.' and the issue/comment *is not* created.  If the email is 'bulk' but the MailHandler does not have a valid config for 'bulk=', it will be processed as any regular (i.e. non bulk) mail. Note: this assumption needs to be tested, the MailHandler might set a default 'bulk' value)  {quote}  We think the doc need to add more information, as in it does not include the multipart/report cases, it does not mention that *not* configuring bulk will include those emails in the regular process (see note above) and does not makes it clear enough that configuring 'bulk' means those bulk emails will not create issues/comments.
